- Change in the frequency, severity, or pattern of angina
- Modification of risk factors
- New or worsened comorbid illnesses (diabetes, hypercholesterolemia)

column2: Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Lipids/A1C if due
Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, A1c result
Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, ER and likely IPD admission
column6:
IF ill appearing; with diaphoresis, vomiting, chest pain treat as Unstable Angina / NSTEMI
-oxygen
-give aspirin 75mg X 4 tablets (300mg) po stat
-atorvastatin 80mg po stat
-if BP>100 systolic give sublingual nitroglycerin
- if BP>100 systolic give atenolol 50
-morphine 2mg IV can repeat 5-15min
-stat EKG -insert IV and draw troponin -call medical doctor

column2: Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Refer to outside hospital
column6:
If patient appears clinically stable, but complaints of angina despite max dose 1st line agents + 2nd line agents-->
consider referral to Kathmandu for stress+angio

column2: Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Assessment
column6:
- Stable angina, no change in medicine → 3months
- Symptoms uncontrolled, uptitrate medicines/ or add second line agent (SEE medication page) → 2 weeks
- Suspected unstable angina / acute MI → SEND TO ER
- Other cause of chest pain likely, not cardiac → manage and 3 months follow up unless unstable, then ER

column2: Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Management
Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Checklist
column6:
- Baseline ECG then q12mo.
- Screen 6mo. A1C goal <7
- Screen lipids q6mo.LDL<100
- Control htn goal <130/

column2: Coronary Heart Disease, Followup, Preventive therapies
column6:
- aspirin 100mg po unless contraindications
- atorvastatin start 20mg po qhs if past MI, OR to treat LDL goal
COUNSELING
- smoking/diet/exercise
